The supremum of the principal segment

type: {Œ± : Type u_4} ‚Üí {Œ≤ : Type u_5} ‚Üí {r : Œ± ‚Üí Œ± ‚Üí Prop} ‚Üí {s : Œ≤ ‚Üí Œ≤ ‚Üí Prop} ‚Üí r ‚â∫i s ‚Üí Œ≤
name: PrincipalSeg.top
docString: The supremum of the principal segment

In a convex set of an additive commutative monoid that is a module over an ordered semiring, any segment connecting two elements lies entirely within the set.

type:
‚àÄ {ùïú : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} [inst : OrderedSemiring ùïú] [inst_1 : AddCommMonoid E] [inst_2 : SMul ùïú E] {s : Set E},
  Convex ùïú s ‚Üí ‚àÄ {x y : E}, x ‚àà s ‚Üí y ‚àà s ‚Üí segment ùïú x y ‚äÜ s
name: Convex.segment_subset
docString: In a convex set of an additive commutative monoid that is a module over an ordered semiring, any segment connecting two elements lies entirely within the set.

The theorem `Convex.segment_subset` states that for any ordered semiring `ùïú` and any additive commutative monoid `E` that is also a `ùïú`-module, if `s` is a convex set in `E`, then for any two elements `x` and `y` in `s`, the segment from `x` to `y` (which is defined as the set of all points `z` that can be expressed as `a*x + b*y`, where `a` and `b` are nonnegative and sum to 1) is a subset of `s`. In other words, in a convex set, the entire line segment connecting any two points in the set also lies within the set.

type:
‚àÄ {ùïú : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} [inst : OrderedSemiring ùïú] [inst_1 : AddCommMonoid E] [inst_2 : SMul ùïú E] {s : Set E},
  Convex ùïú s ‚Üí ‚àÄ {x y : E}, x ‚àà s ‚Üí y ‚àà s ‚Üí segment ùïú x y ‚äÜ s
name: Convex.segment_subset
docString: The theorem `Convex.segment_subset` states that for any ordered semiring `ùïú` and any additive commutative monoid `E` that is also a `ùïú`-module, if `s` is a convex set in `E`, then for any two elements `x` and `y` in `s`, the segment from `x` to `y` (which is defined as the set of all points `z` that can be expressed as `a*x + b*y`, where `a` and `b` are nonnegative and sum to 1) is a subset of `s`. In other words, in a convex set, the entire line segment connecting any two points in the set also lies within the set.

Being a nonempty initial segment of colex is equivalent to being an `initSeg`.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrder Œ±] {ùíú : Finset (Finset Œ±)} {r : ‚Ñï} [inst_1 : Fintype Œ±],
  Finset.Colex.IsInitSeg ùíú r ‚àß ùíú.Nonempty ‚Üî ‚àÉ s, s.card = r ‚àß ùíú = Finset.Colex.initSeg s
name: Finset.Colex.isInitSeg_iff_exists_initSeg
docString: Being a nonempty initial segment of colex is equivalent to being an `initSeg`.

If the germ of a section is a unit in the stalk of a Ringed Space at a point, then the section is a unit in some neighborhood of that point.

type:
‚àÄ (X : AlgebraicGeometry.RingedSpace) (U : TopologicalSpace.Opens ‚Üë‚ÜëX.toPresheafedSpace)
  (f : ‚Üë(X.presheaf.obj (Opposite.op U))) (x : ‚Ü•U),
  IsUnit ((X.presheaf.germ x) f) ‚Üí ‚àÉ V i, ‚àÉ (_ : ‚Üëx ‚àà V), IsUnit ((X.presheaf.map i.op) f)
name: AlgebraicGeometry.RingedSpace.isUnit_res_of_isUnit_germ
docString: If the germ of a section is a unit in the stalk of a Ringed Space at a point, then the section is a unit in some neighborhood of that point.

This theorem in Algebraic Geometry, specifically in the context of Ringed Spaces, asserts that if the germ of a section `f` under a presheaf is a unit in the stalk at a point `x`, then the section `f` itself must be a unit in some small neighborhood around `x` in the underlying topological space of the Ringed Space. Here, a "unit" refers to an element having a two-sided inverse in the monoid structure. The germ of a section represents a local piece or an "infinitesimal neighborhood" around the point, and the theorem essentially states a sort of local-to-global principle: if a property holds at the 'infinitesimal' or germ level, then it also holds in some 'small' neighborhood.

type:
‚àÄ (X : AlgebraicGeometry.RingedSpace) (U : TopologicalSpace.Opens ‚Üë‚ÜëX.toPresheafedSpace)
  (f : ‚Üë(X.presheaf.obj (Opposite.op U))) (x : ‚Ü•U),
  IsUnit ((X.presheaf.germ x) f) ‚Üí ‚àÉ V i, ‚àÉ (_ : ‚Üëx ‚àà V), IsUnit ((X.presheaf.map i.op) f)
name: AlgebraicGeometry.RingedSpace.isUnit_res_of_isUnit_germ
docString: This theorem in Algebraic Geometry, specifically in the context of Ringed Spaces, asserts that if the germ of a section `f` under a presheaf is a unit in the stalk at a point `x`, then the section `f` itself must be a unit in some small neighborhood around `x` in the underlying topological space of the Ringed Space. Here, a "unit" refers to an element having a two-sided inverse in the monoid structure. The germ of a section represents a local piece or an "infinitesimal neighborhood" around the point, and the theorem essentially states a sort of local-to-global principle: if a property holds at the 'infinitesimal' or germ level, then it also holds in some 'small' neighborhood.
